General.name: Carter S. Godin
General.label: Software Engineer and Data Analyst
General.summary: Software architect, machine learning, and data analysis specialist with over 4 years of experience designing and deploying production systems in local and cloud environments. Background in building and optimizing scalable data and processing pipelines and microservices using Docker, Kubernetes, Python, and CI/CD tools. Expertise in workflow automation, and performance tuning, with strong experience translating stakeholder needs into robust technical solutions.

work.name: Lincoln Laboratory, Massachusetts Institute of Technology
work.summary: Directed and executed the design of software and Machine Learning-based data analysis systems. Utilized Python, Docker, and Kubernetes to build scalable systems and Jenkins, TeamCity to enable DevSecOps.

work.name: Lincoln Laboratory, Massachusetts Institute of Technology
work.summary: Conducted agile development of multi-threaded data analysis algorithms within existing enterprise system, resulting in first-ever detections of critical results, and processing time reductions of up to 50%. Utilized end-to-end CI/CD pipline in Jenkins for testing, code analysis/scanning, build and deployment.

work.name: Brookhaven National Laboratory
work.summary: Designed installation hardware and complex loading procedures on the Relativistic Heavy Ion Collider sPHENIX experiment. Utilized Matlab to implement low-tolerance numerical schemes simulating structural load and stress distributions in the detector’s hardware.Advised chief mechanical engineer on issues of cost, safety, and viability.

work.name: Mid-Atlantic Regional Spaceport
work.summary: Used SolidWorks facilities design tools to create integrated design schematics of FGSE equipment and pad structure for Rocket Lab’s LC2 launch complex. Designed and built a database of Fluid Ground Support Equipment system information for the Antares mission Pad-0A to document and track component service history for mission assurance.

volunteer.summary: Assisted in teaching EM theory, special relativity, optics graded homework assignments and tests. Set up and aided students in experiments and hosted 4 monthly exam prep sessions per semester. Held office hours to assist students with homework and exam preparation.

Supervised a floor of ~40 first-year students. Planned and executed monthly educational and social programs to foster community and personal growth. Served as a resource for students in crisis and referred them to campus resources as needed.

education.area: Aeronautical Engineering, Conc. Space Vehicle Design

awards.title: Nobel Prize in Physics
awards.summary: The Nobel Prizes are five separate prizes that, according to Alfred Nobel's will of 1895, are awarded to 'those who, during the preceding year, have conferred the greatest benefit to humankind.'

publications.name: Zur Elektrody/namik bewegter Körper
publications.summary: It concerned an interpretation of the Michelson–Morley experiment and the properties of light and time. Special relativity incorporates the principle that the speed of light is the same for all inertial observers regardless of the state of motion of the source.

publications.name: Über einen die Erzeugung und Verwandlung des Lichtes betreffenden heuristischen Gesichtspunkt
publications.summary: In the second paper, he applied the quantum theory to light to explain the photoelectric effect. In particular, he used the idea of light quanta (photons) to explain experimental results, but stressed the importance of the experimental results. The importance of his work on the photoelectric effect earned him the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1921.

publications.name: Die Grundlage der allgemeinen Relativitätstheorie
publications.summary: The publication of the theory of general relativity made him internationally famous. He was professor of physics at the universities of Zurich (1909–1911) and Prague (1911–1912), before he returned to ETH Zurich (1912–1914).

projects.name: Quantum Computing
projects.summary: Quantum computing is the use of quantum-mechanical phenomena such as superposition and entanglement to perform computation. Computers that perform quantum computations are known as quantum computers.
